The ESIA, which includes major players like NXP, Nexperia, GlobalFoundries, and Intel, suggests that Europe should concentrate on mature chip processes rather than trying to compete with cutting-edge technology.  ## Current State of European Chip Manufacturing  European chip manufacturing has traditionally excelled in producing legacy chips using mature processes. Recent projects, such as the ESMC joint venture involving TSMC, Bosch, Siemens, and NXP, continue to focus on this area. These chips are based on older nodes that are no longer considered cutting-edge but still have significant applications.  For context, while TSMC's 28nm process was state-of-the-art in 2011, producing advanced CPUs, GPUs, and SoCs, it is now used for less complex chips. Meanwhile, companies like Apple and Nvidia have moved on to much more advanced 3-4 nanometer processes.  ## Shift in EU Chip Strategy  The ESIA has responded positively to the appointment of Henna Virkkunen as EU Commissioner-designate for the chip industry. Both the ESIA and Virkkunen advocate for emphasizing mature processes, such as 28nm, for legacy chip production. This approach aims to cater to the needs of the automotive and industrial sectors, which often rely on less advanced chip technologies.  This shift represents a return to the original intent of the EU Chips Act, which was initially conceived as a response to COVID-related supply chain issues. Over time, the act evolved to include ambitions of making Europe competitive with East Asia and the U.S. in advanced chip production. However, the dominance of non-European players like TSMC, Samsung, and Intel in cutting-edge chip manufacturing has made this goal increasingly unrealistic.  ## Implications for European Chip Industry  While focusing on legacy chip production aligns with Europe's current strengths, it also means that the continent may never achieve complete autonomy in its chip industry supply chain. Modern technologies, including software-driven vehicles, require a mix of legacy chips and advanced processors that are economical, fast, and versatile.  Despite these limitations, Europe maintains a strong position in the global chip industry through companies like Imec and ASML. This underscores the reality that the chip industry is inherently globalized, and while Europe has an important role to play, it cannot operate in isolation.  In conclusion, the EU's dream of building advanced chips has indeed faced significant challenges, leading to a more pragmatic approach focused on leveraging existing strengths in legacy chip production and maintaining a vital role in the global semiconductor value chain.

text: NVIDIA Data Science (DL Engineer) Interview Question: How do you choose between CBOW and Skip-gram architctures?  𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗲𝘁 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲 Skip-Gram performs better with smaller datasets because it creates more training examples from each input sentence. For each word, it generates multiple context-word pairs, effectively increasing the amount of training data. CBOW, by averaging context words, benefits more from larger datasets where it has enough examples to learn robust representations.  𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 Skip-Gram handles rare words better because it treats each context-target word pair as a separate training example, giving equal importance to rare and frequent words. CBOW, by averaging context words, tends to smooth over distributional information, leading to better representations for frequent words but potentially less accurate representations for rare words.  𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 CBOW typically trains faster because it predicts a single target word from multiple context words in one forward pass. Skip-Gram, conversely, predicts multiple context words for each target word, requiring more computations per training example.  𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗼𝘄 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲 Skip-Gram can handle larger context windows more effectively because it directly models the relationship between each target word and its context words. CBOW, by averaging context words, may lose some of the nuanced relationships in larger contexts, making it more suitable for smaller window sizes.  𝗦𝗲𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗖𝗮𝗽𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 Skip-Gram often captures semantic relationships better because it learns to predict each context word independently. This allows it to pick up on subtle semantic differences and relationships between words. CBOW, by averaging context, may miss some of these finer distinctions.  𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝘂𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲𝘀 CBOW generally requires fewer parameters because it averages context word vectors before prediction, resulting in a smaller model size. text: A inteligência artificial generativa, capaz de criar textos, imagens e outros conteúdos, tem revolucionado diversos setores. No entanto, sua ascensão tem sido acompanhada por uma série de controvérsias, especialmente no campo das artes e da cultura.  Um estudo recente, publicado por Alex Reisner na revista The Atlantic, revelou um dado alarmante: modelos de linguagem de grande porte (LLMs) foram treinados com mais de 139 mil diálogos de filmes e séries, incluindo clássicos como "Os Simpsons" e "Breaking Bad". Essa descoberta tem gerado um intenso debate sobre os direitos autorais e a ética no desenvolvimento da IA.  O material não foi retirado de roteiros oficiais, mas de legendas publicadas no site. Essas legendas, extraídas de DVDs, Blu-rays e streams online, servem como fonte por refletirem diálogos naturais, essenciais para ensinar chatbots a simular conversas. Essa prática, no entanto, envolve questões legais, já que legendas podem ser consideradas obras derivadas e protegidas por direitos autorais.  Empresas como Apple, Meta, Anthropic e Nvidia utilizaram essas legendas para treinar sistemas como Claude, OPT e NeMo Megatron. Além disso, organizações como Salesforce e Bloomberg criaram mais de 140 modelos de IA de código aberto com os mesmos dados, tudo sem permissão dos autores originais.  O OpenSubtitles oferece arquivos acessíveis a qualquer pessoa, mas com estrutura difícil de interpretar. O conjunto de dados, com 14 GB, inclui diálogos organizados em 446.612 arquivos, separados por IDs do IMDb. Reisner identificou cerca de 139 mil títulos únicos e mapeou informações como diretores e atores.  As empresas envolvidas não comentaram as acusações. A questão dos direitos autorais na era da IA é complexa e multifacetada, e suas implicações se estendem muito além do mundo do entretenimento.  Qual a sua opinião?  Siga @cataiportal  📰imdb

The chatbot uses xAI's proprietary large language model, Grok-2 and has been a notable part of the company's portfolio. Elon Musk has openly said that his social media platform, X, is being used to help train xAI's Grok chatbot. By tapping into the conversations and posts on X, the chatbot can learn to respond more naturally and relevantly. News portals were reporting that India’s had been hacked. At first, he thought that meant a “technical glitch” and things would get back to normal. The full extent of his misfortune was yet to be revealed.  “My cousin told me some Rs 2,000 crore had been stolen from the company,” said the 32-year-old man. “I immediately rushed to withdraw my Rs 7 lakh investment on WazirX but it was too late--no transactions were allowed.”  The prospect of never being able to get his money back has caused sleeplessness, anxiety, emotional distress and setbacks in business. At home, he pretends nothing has happened. “My wife thinks I do some stock market trade,” he said. “She doesn’t understand crypto stuff--she thinks we are rich.”  He dwells on what might have been.  “Every day, I take a pen and paper (to calculate) and tell my co-worker that today the value of my crypto would have been Rs 25 lakh,” he said. “(Auto) agency guys would have given us so much business on such credit.”  About 15 million users of WazirX were victims of one of the largest cyberattacks on a cryptocurrency exchange in July, leading to the theft of investor holdings worth $235 million or nearly half of the platform's estimated reserves. Since then, the remaining funds on the platform have been frozen and trading has been halted.  Somewhere the thief (or thieves) who masterminded this heist is watching the tokens swell in value in the ongoing crypto bull run. As per an analysis of Lookonchain data, that $235 million will now be valued at about $330 million.  Crypto prices have skyrocketed in the past month following the victory of Donald Trump—a sceptic-turned-champion—in the US elections. In the past month, crypto market cap has grown from $2.4 trillion to $3.7 trillion, surpassing that of companies like Apple and Nvidia.  Netherlands-based blockchain intelligence firm Crystal Intelligence recently said that the WazirX thief has almost finished laundering the stolen funds via TornadoCash. Only $6 million of Ether (ETH) remains traceable. TornadoCash is an open source, non-custodial, fully decentralised cryptocurrency platform that shuffles crypto tokens, making it difficult to track the source of funds and recover any stolen money.

position: On the retraining train
text: cont'd 2 of 2 The data pyramid is one of three key principles underpinning work on GR00T.  Moravecs paradox states that machines struggle to perform at things humans find easy.  Team GR00T believes training data is the key to overcoming Moravec. However, the  exabytes of text and video data available to existing models, while  useful base  information, is inadequate for robots to learn proprioception and motor skills.  The pyramid needs to be built out with real robot training data – high value but limited due to time constraints and supplemented with more copious robot simulation data.  Here NVIDIA has been able to utilise clever tools and its titanic compute resource to simulate massive amounts of data in an environment called Omniverse. The importance of simulation is the backbone of the second “Matrix principle”. Generative AI  can create a multiplier effect from a few human based examples to thousands of virtual actions and in different environments, like climbing a flight of stairs.  Agents can then optimise this data in two learning paradigms. Reinforcement learning is an effective method for learning those intuitive motor actions we don’t even think about, rebalancing after a stumble, for example. Those thousands of simulations can also be used in imitation learning, to best mimic human manipulation of various objects and tasks, such as making a cup of coffee. The final core principle is the foundation agent – the idea that one neural network can be used for all humanoid robots, despite physical design differences, for all tasks. Again, mass simulation is what enables putting this principle into practice.   Interestingly the project team found GPT highly proficient at creating and optimising  Python code reward functions for the agent, including very complex actions such as spinning a pen through the fingers of one hand.  Tens of thousands of simulations of an action may not exactly represent the real world, but if generalisation holds the model will be able to learn the nth + 1 simulation in the real world.

name: Barney Geerligs
position: On the retraining train
text: 1 of 2 Agents and models - we’re not talking Bond movies here, rather agentic applications using large language models (LLMs). In tandem, these two hot topics offer us all the pinky promise and furrowed-brow worry of increasing automation and autonomous decision making, based primarily on natural language prompting. If you are curious about this burgeoning area, I can thoroughly recommend the free  LLM and Agents course currently offered by UC Berkeley RDI. Things I really like about the course (apart from being a freebie) ·       An “AI A-list” of weekly guest speakers kindly sharing their knowledge and practical experience and insights into the sprawling and rapidly developing field of agentic AI ·       Optionality around participation – pop in to a recorded guest lecture or go for full ninja certification by completing quizzes, labs and hackathon. ·       Engaging content, including fun real-world labs that require a basic level of Python understanding. Now, in the interests of full disclosure, one of the course requirements is to summarise and post one of the guest speaker’s lectures. I’ll go with Jim Fan’s fascinating presentation of his team’s work into robotics at NVIDIA. The moonshot ambition is to build a foundational model (cutely named GR00T)  for humanoid robots, creating an embodied AI brain enabling robots to perceive, react and perform actions as we do. The scale of the challenge is immense, dwarfing the size and complexity of LLMs, such as ChatGPT. Why make robots in our own image, when specialised robots may perform specific tasks better? One aspect is social, we feel more comfortable in the presence of machines like us.  Another reason is practical, our built environments are purposed for our human form, so humanoid robots will fit in well.  Of course, money is a key motivator too, the economic opportunity of a humanoid workforce is revolutionary.  The risk of ensuing  mass unemployment is a definite worry point for us biological humans, although, breezily,  Jim Fan skips this threat. GR00T aims to be a “specialised generalist” – providing the foundation for humanoid robots to become domain experts. Jim Fan draws the analogy of an LLM becoming special purpose (in coding, for example) after prompting, distillation and finetuning.  He maintains that history is on the side of the specialised generalist, being in the long run, cheaper and easier to maintain than an array of specialist applications, each with their own production pipeline.
